ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I did not find this class to be particularly well-taught. I did come away from this class with a stronger grasp of Latin than when I came in, and the readings were interesting (if not a bit repetitive). However, I am not sure if that can be directly attributed to Prof. Solodow. Much of that came from painstakingly reading the commentary. The work load I found to be unpredictable and widely varying: the number of lines we were supposed to translate varied from 30 to 90 every Monday and Wednesday. Consider that it is held at 9:00 a.m. every morning. It is a very impersonal setting. Prof. Solodow comes off as very cool and oftentimes unapproachable, even if he is very knowledgeable about the topic. I did not find the papers to be helpful, as they were only supposed to be three and a half pages, which I found to be too short to say anything interesting. It was sometimes slightly uncomfortable to discuss body parts or sex positions in class, as they related to the text. I probably would have been better off taking another upper-division Latin course offered this semester.
